titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James De Lancey speech 1978.089
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:19:30 +0000.

did.abstract: Printed speech of James De Lancey, in which he sets out instructions for the people of New York based on the wishes of King George III. Dated 1783. James De Lancey (1703-1760) was the Lieutenant Governor of the English Province of New York from 1753 to 1760.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1978.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); James De Lancey speech, 1978.089, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: James De Lancey (1703-1760) was the Lieutenant Governor of the English Province of New York from 1753 to 1760.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed speech of James De Lancey, in which he sets out instructions for the people of New York based on the wishes of King George III. Dated 1783.

controlaccess.persname: George, King of Great Britain, III
